question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions about the salariesand allowances of members of the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council of a state?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Article 195 of the Indian Constitution mentions the salaries and allowances of the members of the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council of a State.
  • It empowers the State Legislature to determine the salaries, allowances, and privileges of its members.
  • The salaries and allowances are paid from the Consolidated Fund of the State.

Additional Information:

  • Article 194: Deals with the powers, privileges, and immunities of the State Legislature and its members.
  • Article 198: It deals with special procedure in respect of Money Bills in State Legislatures.
  • Article 199: It defines what constitutes a Money Bill in State Legislatures, similar to Article 110 for Parliament.
  • Article 195 ensures financial provisions for state legislators to perform their duties effectively.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that a person may be appointed as the Governor of two or more states?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Article 153 of the Indian Constitution mentions that a person may be appointed as the Governor of two or more States.
  • This article provides flexibility in the appointment of Governors and allows the President to appoint the same person as Governor for multiple states if deemed necessary.
  • It helps in administrative convenience and resource optimization.

Additional Information:

  • Article 153: Provides for a Governor in each state and allows the same person to be appointed as Governor of two or more states.
  • Article 152: Defines the term “State” for Part VI; excludes Jammu & Kashmir.
  • Article 151: Deals with CAG reports to the Governor.
  • Article 150: Prescribes format for accounts of the Union and States.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution states that “There shall be a

High Court for each state”?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• Article 214 of the Indian Constitution states that “There shall be a High Court for each State.”
  • This article establishes the existence of a High Court in every state to administer justice at the state level.
  • The High Court is the highest judicial authority within a state.

Additional Information:

  • Article 275: Deals with grants from the Union to certain states.
  • Article 245: Concerns the extent of laws made by Parliament and State Legislatures.
  • Article 125: Relates to the salaries and allowances of Supreme Court judges.
  • Article 214 is fundamental to the judicial structure in India.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that ‘All the executive action of the Government of a state shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the Governor’?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• Article 166(1) of the Indian Constitution mentions that “All the executive action of the Government of a State shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the Governor.”
  • This means that every executive order or action by the State Government is formally issued in the Governor’s name, symbolizing the Governor as the constitutional head of the state.

Additional Information:

  • Article 163(1): Deals with the Council of Ministers to aid and advise the Governor.
  • Article 164(1): Pertains to the appointment of the Chief Minister and other ministers.
  • Article 165(1): Provides for the appointment of the Advocate-General of the State.
  • Article 166(1) ensures the Governor’s constitutional authority in state executive actions.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions the qualification for membership of the State Legislature?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Article 173 of the Indian Constitution mentions the qualification for membership of the State Legislature.
  • This article specifies the qualifications required for a person to be chosen as a member of the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of a state.
  • It includes conditions such as age, citizenship, and other criteria as prescribed by law.

Additional Information:

  • Article 171: Deals with the composition of the State Legislative Councils.
  • Article 179: Relates to the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly.
  • Article 180: Concerns the disqualification of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly.
  • Article 173 is important for ensuring eligible and qualified candidates represent the people in state legislatures.

question:
What Article of the Indian Constitution provides that the State Governor has the authority to reserve a bill for the consideration of the President

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Article 200 of the Indian Constitution provides that the Governor of a State has the authority to reserve a Bill for the consideration of the President.
  • When a Bill is passed by the State Legislature, the Governor may either give assent, withhold assent, or reserve the Bill for the President’s consideration.
  • This article acts as a constitutional check and balances mechanism between the State and the Union.

Additional Information:

  • Article 181: Relates to the power of the Governor to address the State Legislature and send messages.
  • Article 190: Deals with rules of procedure in State Legislatures.
  • Article 267: Concerns the Contingency Fund of India.
  • Article 200 is important for maintaining the relationship between the State legislature and the Union government.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution deals with the annual financial statement of the Government of India?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is Article 112 of the Indian Constitution, which deals with the Annual Financial Statement (Union Budget) of the Government of India.
  • Article 112 mandates the presentation of the estimated receipts and expenditure of the government to both Houses of Parliament annually.
  • It forms the constitutional basis for the Union Budget process.

Additional Information:

  • Article 112: Annual Financial Statement (Union Budget).
  • Article 110: Defines Money Bills.
  • Article 116: Deals with Votes on account, votes of credit, and exceptional grants.
  • Article 120: Rules of procedure in Parliament.
  • Article 360: Deals with Financial Emergency.

question:
________ of the Indian Constitution sets qualifications for being a member of Lok Sabha.

Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• Article 84 of the Indian Constitution sets the qualifications for being a member of the Lok Sabha.
  • It specifies criteria such as age, citizenship, and other qualifications prescribed by law for membership in either House of Parliament.
  • The minimum age for Lok Sabha membership is 25 years.

Additional Information:

  • Article 74: Relates to the Council of Ministers to aid and advise the President.
  • Article 64: Deals with the appointment of the Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha.
  • Article 76: Pertains to the Attorney General of India.
  • Article 84 is important for ensuring eligible candidates represent the people in the Lok Sabha.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution are related to the Comptroller and Auditor General of India?

Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
solution:
• Articles 148 to 151 of the Indian Constitution are related to the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India.
  • These articles deal with the appointment, duties, powers, and conditions of service of the CAG, who audits the accounts of the Union and State governments.

Additional Information:

  • Article 147-150: Are not related to the CAG.
  • Article 152: Relates to the appointment of Governors of States.
  • Article 153 onwards: Deal with Governors and State executive.
  • The CAG plays a crucial role in ensuring transparency and accountability in government finances.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution makes it clear that Directive Principles of State Policy Are fundamental in the governance of the country and it shall be the duty of the state to apply these principles in making laws?

Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• Article 37 of the Indian Constitution makes it clear that the Directive Principles of State Policy are fundamental in the governance of the country.
  • It states that these principles are not enforceable by any court, but it shall be the duty of the State to apply these principles in making laws.
  • This article emphasizes the importance of Directive Principles as guidelines for the government.

Additional Information:

  • Article 40: Deals with the organisation of village Panchayats.
  • Article 44: Relates to the Uniform Civil Code.
  • Article 46: Promotes the educational and economic interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and other weaker sections.
  • Article 37 forms the constitutional foundation for the Directive Principles.

question:
Which of the following does NOT come under the Concurrent List?

Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• Artificial Habitats does NOT come under the Concurrent List of the Indian Constitution.
  • The Concurrent List includes subjects on which both the Union and State governments can legislate, such as Medical Education, Protection of Wildlife, and Population Control.
  • Artificial Habitats is not mentioned explicitly in the Concurrent List.

Additional Information:

  • The Concurrent List is List III in the Seventh Schedule of the Constitution.
  • It includes topics like education, forests, wildlife protection, population control, and other social and economic issues.
  • Matters not included in the Union or Concurrent Lists fall under the State List.

question:
In respect of Arunachal Pradesh, the Governor has special responsibility under ________ of the Constitution of India with respect to law and order and in discharge of his functions in relation thereto.

Higher Secondary 26/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
solution:
• In respect of Arunachal Pradesh, the Governor has special responsibility under Article 371H of the Indian Constitution regarding law and order and in the discharge of his functions related thereto.
  • This article grants the Governor special powers to ensure peace and good governance in Arunachal Pradesh, including oversight over the state’s police and law and order.

Additional Information:

  • Article 359A: Relates to suspension of fundamental rights during an emergency.
  • Article 380A: Does not exist in the Constitution.
  • Article 361H: Does not exist in the Constitution.
  • Article 371H is specific to Arunachal Pradesh, ensuring special administrative provisions.

question:
Under which Schedule of the Indian Constitution is the form of oath or affirmation for a Judge of the Supreme Court mentioned?

Graduate Level 20/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• The form of oath or affirmation for a Judge of the Supreme Court is mentioned under the Third Schedule of the Indian Constitution.
  • The Third Schedule contains the various forms of oaths or affirmations for different constitutional positions, including the President, Judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts, Ministers, and members of Parliament.

Additional Information:

  • First Schedule: Deals with the territories of India.
  • Second Schedule: Contains provisions relating to salaries, allowances, and privileges of constitutional officials.
  • Fourth Schedule: Allocates seats in the Rajya Sabha (Council of States) to the States and Union territories.
  • The Third Schedule is essential for the formal constitutional oath-taking process.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that ‘In the performance of his/her duties, the Attorney- General for India shall have the right of audience in all the courts in the territory of India’?

Graduate Level 20/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• Article 76(3) of the Indian Constitution mentions that in the performance of his/her duties, the Attorney-General for India shall have the right of audience in all the courts in the territory of India.
  • This provision empowers the Attorney-General to appear and represent the Government of India in any court, including the Supreme Court and High Courts.
  • The Attorney-General is the highest law officer of the country.

Additional Information:

  • Article 76(1): Provides for the appointment of the Attorney-General by the President.
  • Article 76(2): Deals with the duties and powers of the Attorney-General.
  • Article 76(4): The Attorney-General shall hold office during the pleasure of the President, and shall receive such remuneration as the President may determine.
  • Article 76(3) ensures the Attorney-General’s legal authority throughout India.

question:
Which Article of the Constitution of India mentions that “there shall be a Public Service Commission for the Union and a Public Service Commission for each State”?

SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Article 315(1) of the Indian Constitution states that “there shall be a Public Service Commission for the Union and a Public Service Commission for each State.”
  • This article establishes the constitutional provision for setting up Public Service Commissions at both the Union and State levels.
  • These Commissions are responsible for conducting examinations and selecting candidates for civil services and other government posts.

Additional Information:

  • The Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) conducts exams such as the Civil Services Examination and Engineering Services Examination for recruitment to central government posts.
  • Each State has its own State Public Service Commission, responsible for recruitment to state government services.
  • Article 315 guarantees the autonomy and impartiality of these Commissions, ensuring fair recruitment processes.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Constitution of India provides that the Governor appoints the Chief Minister and later, the Chief Minister recommends the appointment of ministers to the Governor?

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Article 164 of the Indian Constitution provides that the Governor appoints the Chief Minister and on the advice of the Chief Minister, the Governor appoints the other ministers.
  • It outlines the procedure for the formation of the Council of Ministers at the state level and specifies their responsibilities.
  • This article is crucial for the functioning of the state government under the parliamentary system.

Additional Information:

  • Article 163: Deals with the Council of Ministers to aid and advise the Governor.
  • Article 165: Provides for the appointment of the Advocate-General of the State.
  • Article 167: Specifies the duties of the Chief Minister regarding information to the Governor.
  • Article 164 establishes the constitutional process for ministerial appointments in states.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution empowers the Parliament to restrict or abrogate the fundamental rights of the members of the armed forces, paramilitary forces, police forces, intelligence agencies and analogous forces?

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Article 33 of the Indian Constitution empowers Parliament to restrict or abrogate the fundamental rights of members of the armed forces, paramilitary forces, police forces, intelligence agencies, and analogous forces.
  • This provision ensures that the functioning of these forces is not hindered by certain fundamental rights that may conflict with their duties related to security and discipline.

Additional Information:

  • Article 31: Relates to the right to property (now repealed).
  • Article 35: Contains general provisions regarding the enforcement of fundamental rights.
  • Article 37: Deals with Directive Principles of State Policy and their non-justiciability.
  • Article 33 is essential for maintaining discipline and efficiency in the security forces.

question:
As per Article 361 of the Constitution of India, who among the following shall NOT be answerable to any court for the exercise and performance of the powers and duties of his/her office?

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• As per Article 361 of the Indian Constitution, the Governor shall NOT be answerable to any court for the exercise and performance of the powers and duties of his office.
  • This article provides immunity to the Governor from legal proceedings during the term of office, protecting them from lawsuits and prosecutions related to official acts.

Additional Information:

  • The President also enjoys similar immunity under Article 361.
  • Other officials like the Prime Minister, Chief Minister, and Secretaries do not have this constitutional immunity.
  • This provision ensures the smooth functioning of constitutional authorities without fear of legal harassment.

question:
Which schedule of the Constitution of India contains provisions for disqualification of legislators on the ground of defection?

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Schedule X of the Indian Constitution contains provisions for the disqualification of legislators on the ground of defection.
  • This schedule was added by the 52nd Amendment Act, 1985, which introduced the anti-defection law to prevent political defections and ensure stability in the legislature.
  • It outlines the grounds and procedures for disqualifying members of Parliament and State Legislatures if they defect from their political party.

Additional Information:

  • Schedule IX: Contains provisions protecting certain acts of Parliament and State Legislatures from judicial review.
  • Schedule VIII: Lists the official languages of India.
  • Schedule XI: Contains provisions related to Panchayats (rural local bodies).
  • Schedule X is vital for maintaining party discipline and preventing opportunistic shifts in legislature.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that all the authorities— civil and judicial— in the territory of India shall act in aid of the Supreme Court?

SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Article 144 of the Indian Constitution mentions that all authorities, civil and judicial, in the territory of India shall act in aid of the Supreme Court.
  • This article ensures that every authority must comply with the Supreme Court’s directions and orders, reinforcing the Court’s position as the highest judicial authority in the country.

Additional Information:

  • Article 141: States that the law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts in India.
  • Article 142: Empowers the Supreme Court to pass any order necessary for doing complete justice in any case.
  • Article 143: Deals with the advisory jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
  • Article 144 is crucial for maintaining the supremacy and authority of the Supreme Court over all civil and judicial bodies.

question:
Article 149 of the Constitution deals with ___________ .

SSC MTS 01/09/2023 (1st Shift)
option_1: the qualifications required for the appointment of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India
option_2: the duties and powers of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India
option_3: the term of office of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India
option_4: the appointment of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India
solution:
• Article 149 of the Indian Constitution deals with the duties and powers of the Comptroller and Auditor-General (CAG) of India.
  • It empowers the CAG to audit all receipts and expenditures of the Government of India and the States, including bodies and authorities substantially financed by the government.
  • The article defines the scope and functions of the CAG in maintaining financial accountability.

Additional Information:

  • Article 148: Provides for the appointment of the CAG.
  • Article 150: Relates to the audit of accounts of states.
  • Article 151: Deals with the reports of the CAG.
  • Article 149 is essential for ensuring transparency and accountability in government finances.

question:
Which of the following statements is correct about Article 129 of the Constitution of India?

SSC MTS 01/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
option_1: It provides for the Supreme Court to give advisory opinions to the President.
option_2: It provides for the Supreme Court to be a court of original jurisdiction
option_3: It provides for the Supreme Court to be a court of record.
option_4: It provides for the Supreme Court to be the highest court of appeal.
solution:
• Article 129 of the Indian Constitution provides that the Supreme Court shall be a court of record.
  • Being a court of record means that the Supreme Court has the power to punish for contempt of itself and that its judicial records are preserved as evidence.
  • This article establishes the Supreme Court’s authority and its role in maintaining judicial discipline.

Additional Information:

  • Article 143: Provides for the Supreme Court’s advisory jurisdiction to give opinions to the President.
  • Article 131: Establishes the Supreme Court as a court of original jurisdiction in disputes involving the Union and States.
  • Article 134: Provides for the Supreme Court as the highest court of appeal in criminal and civil cases.
  • Article 129 is fundamental for the Supreme Court’s legal status and authority.

question:
How many schedules are there in our Constitution as of June 2023?

SSC MTS 05/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• As of June 2023, the Constitution of India has 12 schedules.
  • These schedules contain detailed provisions related to various aspects like allocation of powers, administration of tribal areas, official languages, forms of oath, and others.
  • Over time, the number of schedules has increased through various amendments to accommodate the growing needs of the country.

Additional Information:

  • The original Constitution had 8 schedules at the time of adoption in 1950.
  • Schedules like the 9th, 10th, 11th, and 12th were added later to address specific administrative and regional requirements.
  • The 12th Schedule, added by the 74th Amendment Act, deals with the powers of Municipalities.

question:
Which Clause of Article 19 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the 'right to move freely throughout the territory of India'?

SSC MTS 06/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Clause (d) of Article 19 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the right to move freely throughout the territory of India.
  • This clause provides citizens with the freedom of movement within the country without unreasonable restrictions.

Additional Information:

  • Article 19 protects several fundamental freedoms, including speech, assembly, residence, and movement.
  • Other clauses deal with freedoms such as speech and expression (Clause a), assembly (Clause b), residence and settlement (Clause c).
  • The right to movement is essential for personal liberty and economic freedom.

question:
Which Articles of the Constitution of India deal with the Union and its territory?

SSC MTS 11/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Articles 1 to 4 of the Indian Constitution deal with the Union and its territory.
  • These articles define the territory of India, admission or establishment of new states, formation of new states and alteration of areas, boundaries or names of existing states.
  • They lay the constitutional framework for the political and administrative structure of the Union.

Additional Information:

  • Articles 5 to 11: Deal with citizenship.
  • Articles 12 to 35: Cover Fundamental Rights.
  • Articles 36 to 51: Contain the Directive Principles of State Policy.
  • Articles 1-4 are fundamental for the territorial integrity and political unity of India.

question:
In India which of the following is a Gandhian principle of Directive Principles of State Policy?

SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (1st shift)
option_1: To Separate judiciary from executive
option_2: To organise village panchayat
option_3: To secure uniform civil code
option_4: To provide equal pay for equal work
solution:
• The Gandhian principle among the Directive Principles of State Policy is to organise village panchayats.
  • This is mentioned in Article 40 of the Indian Constitution, which directs the State to take steps to organize village panchayats as units of local self-government.
  • Gandhiji emphasized the importance of Gram Swaraj (village self-rule) for India's democratic and social development.

Additional Information:

  • To separate judiciary from executive: Related to constitutional reforms, not specifically a Gandhian principle.
  • To secure uniform civil code: Mentioned in Article 44, part of Directive Principles but not Gandhian.
  • To provide equal pay for equal work: Mentioned in Article 39(d), but not specifically a Gandhian principle.
  • Organizing village panchayats aligns closely with Gandhian ideals of decentralization and grassroots democracy.

question:
Which of the following Articles says that double jeopardy which says that “no person shall be prosecuted or punished for the same offence more than once?

SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Article 20(2) of the Indian Constitution states the principle of double jeopardy, which means no person shall be prosecuted or punished for the same offence more than once.
  • This article protects individuals from being tried or punished multiple times for the same crime, ensuring fairness in the criminal justice system.

Additional Information:

  • Article 21(2): Does not exist; Article 21 deals with the right to life and personal liberty.
  • Article 19(1): Guarantees certain fundamental freedoms such as speech, assembly, movement, etc.
  • Article 22(2): Deals with protection against arrest and detention in certain cases.
  • Article 20(2) is a vital safeguard for protecting individual rights in criminal law.

question:
Under which Article of the Directive Principles of State Policy, a working woman on maternity leave, must receive all maternity benefits from the employer?

SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Article 42 of the Directive Principles of State Policy in the Indian Constitution states that the State shall make provision for securing just and humane conditions of work and for maternity relief.
  • This means a working woman on maternity leave must receive all maternity benefits from her employer as per the directive.

Additional Information:

  • Article 43: Relates to living wage, etc., for workers.
  • Article 44: Deals with Uniform Civil Code.
  • Article 45: Concerns early childhood care and education.
  • Article 42 emphasizes the protection and welfare of working women, particularly regarding maternity benefits.

question:
'The state shall endeavour to secure to all workers a living wage and a decent standard of life'. Which of the following is correct about the given statement in the context of India?

SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (1st shift)
option_1: It is mentioned in the 43rd Article of the Constitution.
option_2: It is mentioned in the 44th Article of Constitution.
option_3: This is a Gandhian principle of Directive Principles of State Policy.
option_4: This is a liberal principle of Directive Principles of State Policy.
solution:
• The statement "The state shall endeavour to secure to all workers a living wage and a decent standard of life" is mentioned in Article 43 of the Indian Constitution.
  • Article 43 is part of the Directive Principles of State Policy and focuses on the welfare of workers by ensuring fair wages and decent living conditions.
  • This article reflects the commitment of the state towards social and economic justice.

Additional Information:

  • Article 44 deals with the Uniform Civil Code.
  • The statement is not specifically a Gandhian or liberal principle but falls under the broader Directive Principles focused on workers’ welfare.
  • Directive Principles guide the government in policy-making to improve the living standards of citizens.

question:
Which of the following articles is related to the provision of Co-operative Societies in the Indian Constitution?

SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The provision of Co-operative Societies in the Indian Constitution is related to Articles 243ZH to 243ZT.
  • These articles were inserted by the 97th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2011 to provide constitutional status to cooperative societies and outline their structure, powers, and governance.
  • This part ensures the promotion and regulation of cooperative societies as a vital part of the economy.

Additional Information:

  • Articles 243ZG to 243ZJ: Deal with Panchayats.
  • Articles 243P to 243ZG: Relate to Municipalities.
  • Articles 243A to 243O: Concern Panchayats and their powers.
  • The inclusion of cooperative societies in the Constitution strengthens their role in socio-economic development.

question:
The government is bound to ensure observance of social welfare and labour laws enacted to secure for workmen a life compatible with human dignity, under _____ of the Indian Constitution.

SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The government is bound to ensure observance of social welfare and labour laws enacted to secure for workmen a life compatible with human dignity under Article 21 of the Indian Constitution.
  • Article 21 guarantees the right to life and personal liberty, which has been expansively interpreted by the Supreme Court to include the right to a dignified life, including safe working conditions and social welfare.

Additional Information:

  • Article 17: Abolishes untouchability.
  • Article 15: Prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
  • Article 19: Guarantees certain freedoms like speech, assembly, movement, etc.
  • Article 21 is the foundation for protecting workers' rights to life with dignity.

question:
In the Indian Constitution which of the following Articles deals with the right to move to the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental rights?

SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Article 32 of the Indian Constitution deals with the right to move to the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
  • It provides the right to individuals to approach the Supreme Court directly if they believe their Fundamental Rights have been violated.
  • Article 32 is known as the "heart and soul" of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar because it ensures the protection and enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

Additional Information:

  • Article 30: Deals with the rights of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions.
  • Article 33: Allows Parliament to modify the application of Fundamental Rights to armed forces and other services.
  • Article 31: Related to the right to property (now repealed).
  • Article 32 ensures judicial protection of citizens' Fundamental Rights.

question:
Poshan Abhiyaan is a programme to achieve nutritional status of children from 0 to 6 years. Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution provides for raising the nutrition level?

SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Article 47 of the Indian Constitution provides for raising the nutrition level and improving public health.
  • It directs the State to raise the level of nutrition and the standard of living of its people, especially children.
  • Poshan Abhiyaan aligns with this directive, focusing on improving nutritional outcomes for children aged 0 to 6 years.

Additional Information:

  • Article 44: Deals with the Uniform Civil Code.
  • Article 45: Provides for early childhood care and education.
  • Article 46: Promotes the educational and economic interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and other weaker sections.
  • Article 47 is a key part of the Directive Principles of State Policy aimed at public health and nutrition.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution has the idea that 'No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment?

SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• Article 24 of the Indian Constitution states: "No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment."
  • It belongs to the category of Fundamental Rights (Part III of the Constitution).
  • It safeguards children from hazardous labour and exploitation.
  • The provision applies strictly to factories, mines, and other dangerous jobs.

Additional Information:

  • Article 39(e) and (f) under Directive Principles also emphasize child protection.
  • The Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Amendment Act, 2016 enforces a ban on employment of children under 14 in all occupations except family-based, non-hazardous work.
  • The Right to Education Act (RTE), 2009 ensures free and compulsory education for 6–14 year-olds, supporting Article 24’s intent via Article 21A.

question:
KA Najeeb Vs Union of India case deals with violation of rights under_____

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The KA Najeeb vs Union of India case deals with violation of rights under Article 21 of the Indian Constitution.
  • Article 21 guarantees the Right to Life and Personal Liberty.
  • In this case, the Supreme Court highlighted unjustified delay in trial as a violation of personal liberty.
  • The Court ruled that prolonged incarceration without trial infringes the fundamental right to a speedy trial, which is part of Article 21.

Additional Information:

  • The judgment emphasized that bail should not be denied simply because of stringent provisions under special laws (like UAPA) if there is inordinate delay.
  • Article 21 has been interpreted broadly to include the right to live with dignity, healthcare, education, and speedy justice.

question:
Which part of the Constitution of India contains the provisions of the Union Executive?

SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The provisions related to the Union Executive are contained in Part V of the Indian Constitution.
  • Part V deals with The Union, and includes Chapters on:
    • The Executive (President, Vice President, Prime Minister, Council of Ministers, Attorney General)
    • The Parliament
    • The Judiciary
    • The Comptroller and Auditor-General of India
  • Articles 52 to 78 specifically cover the Union Executive.

Additional Information:

  • The Union Executive includes:
    • President of India
    • Vice President
    • Prime Minister
    • Council of Ministers
    • Attorney General of India
  • The President is the constitutional head, while the Prime Minister is the real executive authority.

question:
Fundamental duties were not placed in Part III of the Indian Constitution because Part III is_________.

SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Fundamental Duties were not placed in Part III of the Constitution because Part III is justiciable.
  • Justiciable means the rights under Part III (Fundamental Rights) are legally enforceable by courts.
  • In contrast, Fundamental Duties (added by the 42nd Amendment, 1976) are non-justiciable, meaning they are not enforceable by law.
  • Hence, Fundamental Duties were included in Part IVA (Article 51A) to avoid legal conflict with enforceable Fundamental Rights.

Additional Information:

  • Part III includes Articles 12 to 35 and protects citizens' rights like equality, freedom, and protection against exploitation.
  • Part IVA was added by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976, based on recommendations of the Swaran Singh Committee.
  • India borrowed the concept of Fundamental Duties from the USSR (now Russia).
